module.field:
#includeMacros("macros.macros")
#macro(spoilerInit)
#set ($i = 0)
<script>
function visibilite(thingId)
{
var targetElement;
targetElement = document.getElementById(thingId) ;
if (targetElement.style.display == "none")
{
targetElement.style.display = "" ;
} else {
targetElement.style.display = "none" ;
}
}
</script>
#end

#macro(spoiler $linktext $hiddentext)
<a href="javascript:visibilite('spoiler_$i');"><img src="../module-attachment/$page.project/$page.space.name/$page.name/add.png"></a>
<div id="spoiler_$i" style="display:none;border:1px dotted red;padding:5px;font-style:italic;">$hiddentext</div>
#set ($i = $i + 1)
#end
#spoilerInit()


{show:wiki}
#slide("MP-1855")
{show}

This workshop will show you how to use wiki pages in a professional way. After this Training you will be able to

  • prepare your workspace with recommended development tools.
  • use Polarion default wiki macros.
  • use Velocity scripting in wiki pages.
  • use SQL Queries for wiki Pages.
  • create wiki pages with parameters.
  • use the Polarion API.
  • write your own macros using velocity or Java.
  • write your own workflow extensions.
  • write your own workflow conditions.

Using advances Wiki or API does not only require knowledge about the techniques and coding principles. It is very good practice to prepare the own environment (Notebook/PC) with supporting tools to help you on debugging the code.

So what do we need at all to start with?

  • Installed Polarion Server
  • Admin permissions (ALM license preferred but not mandatory)
  • Eclipse SDK
  • Java SDK 1.7 or later
  • SQL Client (SQuirreL preferred), including H2 database driver.
  • Advanced text editor (Notepad++ preferred)
  • Polarion Scripting Extension

Web Reference: xWiki Organization Platform Syntax  

#spoiler("" "{code} 1 Defects by Priority Report

Priority Highest
{workitems:type:defect AND priority:highest|fields=id,title,status,priority,assignee,timePoint,initialEstimate | sortby=~priority ~status}

Priority High

{workitems:type:defect AND priority:high|fields=id,title,status,priority,assignee,timePoint,initialEstimate | sortby=~priority ~status}

Priority Medium

{workitems:type:defect AND priority:medium|fields=id,title,status,priority,assignee,timePoint,initialEstimate | sortby=~priority ~status}
 
Priority Low

{workitems:type:defect AND priority:low|fields=id,title,status,priority,assignee,timePoint,initialEstimate | sortby=~priority ~status}

Priority Lowest

{workitems:type:defect AND priority:lowest|fields=id,title,status,priority,assignee,timePoint,initialEstimate | sortby=~priority ~status}
{code}")
#spoiler("" "{code}{table:header=no}
Highest | {workitems:type:defect AND priority:highest |display=count}
High | {workitems:type:defect AND priority:high |display=count}
Medium | {workitems:type:defect AND priority:medium |display=count}
Low | {workitems:type:defect AND priority:low |display=count}
Lowest | {workitems:type:defect AND priority:lowest |display=count}
{table}{code}")

If you use some additional formating for this page the dashboard can look like image below but for now our result should be fine.
Example Image:

Polarion is not using the newest version of Velocity. Polarion is using Version 1.4. You can find the Velocity User Guide for Version 1.4 here 

There are single line comments and multi line comments

single line comment 

{code}
## Only this line is a comment
The comment will start soon ... ## this is the comment
{code}

multi line comment 

{code}
#*
 all
 of
 these
 lines
 are
 comments
*#
{code}

There is no variable declaration in Velocity. The variable is declared with the first value assignment. Values to variables are set with the #set statement: 

{code}
#set($var="This is a string") or
#set($var='This is a string')
{code}

The difference between " and ' is that ' takes the whole string as it is and doesn't evaluate anything: 

{code}
#set($string="This is a string")
#set($var1="$string")
#set($var2='$string')
var1= $var1 \\
var2= $var2 \\
{code}

The statements above will display: 

{code}
var1= This is a string
var2= \$string
{code}

This is useful if evaluating should be ommited or if you have mix with " as in: 

{code}
#set($query='document.id:"space/document name"')
query= $query \\
{code}

will display: 

{code}
query= document.id:"space/document name"
{code}

If the assignement is not properly finished: 

{code}
#set($string="This is a string)
{code}

an exception like this will be thrown:

A variable is used also with the $ (as seen above). If a variable is used with text directly following the variable, Velocity provides a seperator: 

{code}
#set($var="Polar")
This is a training from $varion
{code}

displays 

{code}
This is a training from $varion
{code}

In order to display Polarion the following code should be used: 

{code}
#set($var="Polar")
This is a training from ${var}ion
{code}

will be shown as: 

{code}
This is a training from Polarion
{code}

Sometimes the content of a variable could not be determined for instance if a method name could not be found. In these cases it is a good practice to escape via "!": 

{code}
This is my e-mail account $email
This is my e-mail account $!email
{code}

If $email is not assigned a value, the two lines will display: 

{code}
This is my e-mail account $email
This is my e-mail account 
{code}

{} and ! can be mixed: 

{code}
This is my e-mail account $!{email}account
{code}

will work. 

#spoiler("" "{code} ##This is my first Polarion Script
#set($var="Polarion")
This is my first velocity report inside of $var
$varisgood \\
${var}isgood \\
$!varisgood \\
$!{var}isgood
{code}")

Velocity supports the script writer with automatic substitution for getter and setter methods. The following statements are equal. Assume the variable $wi was assigned a workitem object: 

{code}
$wi.getId()
$wi.id
but with mixed lower and capital letter 
$wi.getAvailableActions()
$wi.availableActions
{code}

It should be defined which kind of reference to use. It is good practice to either use one of these two possibilities. This support only works with properties not with methods which have parameters.

By assigning a value to a variable Velocity automatically assigns an object, which can be displayed. The following code will use the different datatypes from Velocity to assign them to different variables: 

{code}
#set($string="This is a string")
#set($bool=true)
#set($number=2)
#set($array=[1,2,3,4])

$string.class \\
$bool.class \\
$number.class \\
$array.class \\
{code}

will display 

{code}
class java.lang.String 
class java.lang.Boolean 
class java.lang.Integer 
class java.util.ArrayList
{code}

This also works with other objects retreived from any other call. Assume the varibale $wi was assigned a workitem object: 

{code}
$wi.class \\
{code}

will display the following class name: 

{code}
class com.polarion.alm.tracker.internal.model.WorkItem
{code}

Polarion objects without the class property are shown like this: 

{code}
PObject(WorkItem; subterra:data-service:objects:/default/wiki${WorkItem}WIKI-19) 
{code}

This is a kind of debugging style to show the class names and/or the Polarion way to render the class. In Velocity it is not possible to create a new object. There is no "new" operator. Due to security reasons to creat new objects, it is necessary to implement a java program which instantiates a new object and returns it to Velocity.

On the extension page such a plugin is available: Polarion wiki scripting tools which should be mandatory if you work with Velocity.

After installing it, the variable $objectFactory is available. If you need a java.util.Map class then newMap() should be called: 

{code}
#set($map=$objectFactory.newMap()) 
#set($oldValue=$map.put("key0","value0"))
#set($oldValue=$map.put("key1","value1"))
map= $map \\
{code}

will display all keys and their values. 

{code}
map= {key0=value0, key1=value1} 
{code}
#spoiler("" "{code}
#set($string="Daniel Morris")  
#set($number=30) 
#set($array=["John","Maria"]) 
 
Name: $string ($string.class) \\
Age: $number ($number.class) \\ 
Parents: $array ($array.class) \\
{code}")
#spoiler("" "{code}
#set($parents=$objectFactory.newMap()) 
#set($oldValue=$parents.put("Father","John"))
#set($oldValue=$parents.put("Mother","Maria"))
Parents = $parents \\
{code}")

Velocity provides if/else and if/elseif/else statements. The following table defines the operators to be used.

Operator   Condition  Example
 ==  equivalent test, both variables should have the same data type  $var1 == $var2
 >  greater than test  $var1 > $var2
<   less than test  $var1 < $var2
>=   greater or equal than test  $var1 >= $var2
<=   less or equal than test  $var1 <= $var2
&&   logical AND test  $var1 && $var2
||   logical OR test  $var1 || $var2
!   logical NOT test, tests if the variable is not true  !$var1 
{code}
#if ($var1 == $var2)
  This is equal
#else
  This is not equal
#end

#if ($var1 == $var2)
  This is equal
#elseif ($var1 > $var2)
  This is greater
#else
  not equal and not greater
#end
{code}

The examples assume the variables are set to some meaningful values. 

#spoiler("" "{code}
#set($age=$objectFactory.newMap()) 
#set($oldValue=$age.put("John",60))
#set($oldValue=$age.put("Maria",56))


#if($age.get("John") == $age.get("Maria")) 
John ($age.get("John")) is as old as Maria ($age.get("Maria"))
#elseif($age.get("John") > $age.get("Maria")) 
John ($age.get("John")) is older than Maria ($age.get("Maria"))
#else
Maria ($age.get("Maria")) is older than John ($age.get("John"))
#end 
{code}")

Velocity only has one loop construct named #foreach where there are three different conditions are possible: 

{code}
#foreach($item in $items) #end -> iterates over the items
#foreach($item in ["A","B","C"]) #end -> iterates over A, B, and C
#foreach($item in [1..5]) #end -> iterates over a range
{code}
#spoiler("" "{code}
#set($family=["John","Maria","Larissa","Gavin","Daniel"])
#foreach($member in $family)
	#if($velocityCount<$family.size())
		$member,
	#else
		$member
	#end
#end
are $family.size() people.
{code}")

Macros in Velocity are grouped statements, which can be called and performed where ever a single statement may be executed. Macros normaly resides in Wiki-Pages and included into other Wiki-Pages whenever the code is needed. 

{code}
Include from another wiki page:
#includeMacro("SPACENAME.WIKINAME") 
Definition of macro:
#macro(macroname $macroparameter) #end
Call of macro:
#macroname($macroparameter)
{code}
#spoiler("" "{code}
#macro(familylist $familymember)
#set($family=$familymember)
#foreach($member in $family)
	#if($velocityCount<$family.size())
		$member,
	#else
		$member
	#end
#end
are $family.size() people.
#end

#familylist(["John","Maria","Larissa","Gavin","Daniel"])\\
#familylist(["Elke","Ludger","Lea","Sarah"])
{code}")

From time to time, Polarion wiki pages can leverage HTML to control the display of information that has been gathered via Velocity scripts, Javascript, and Polarion macros.  In the course of this training, we will cover some of the important programming elements available to HTML as it pertains to Polarion, but it will not be a full treatment of HTML. 

{code}
<table width=300px style="background-color:green">
<tr>
<th>My HTML table</th>
<th>Another table row</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2"><b>Example</b> content</td>
</tr>
</table>
{code}
#spoiler("" "{code}
#set($age=$objectFactory.newMap()) 
#set($oldValue=$age.put("John",60))
#set($oldValue=$age.put("Maria",56))
#set($oldValue=$age.put("Larissa",20))
#set($oldValue=$age.put("Gavin",18))
#set($oldValue=$age.put("Daniel",30))

#set($family=["John","Maria","Larissa","Gavin","Daniel"])

<table width=300px>
	<tr>
		<th>Name</th>
                <th>Age</th>
	</tr>
	#foreach($member in $family)
		<tr><td>$member</td><td>$age.get($member)</td></tr>
	#end
</table>
{code}")

If you are working with Wiki-Pages it is necessary to get data from the user in order to display information. Normally you have to deal with the the $request class to obtain the parameter from the URL. Polarion provides makro which gives you the opportunity to handle parameter from Wiki-Pages easily. The following statement defines a parameter: 

{code}
(parameter:query|type=string|value=type:requirement)
{code}

The name is query and the type is a string. This definition can also be used for any parameter which are send to the current wiki page. If the wiki page is called with 

{code}
http://server:port/polarion/#/wiki/space/document?query=type:requirement
{code}

the parameter query contains the parameter from the URL: 

{code}
IGONRE ":" at start of "parameter:query" in next line paramter should be added without ":"
{:parameter:query|type=string|value=type:requirement}
query= $pageParameters.query \\
{code}

will display query=type:requirement if the page is called without any parameter. But if the page is called with ?query=type:usecase the page parameter is set to type:usecase.

If the user should enter data into the Wiki page, Polarion offers a macro to define the entry form and input fields specific to the datatype of the parameter. Details can be found in the Polarion Detailed Syntax help, available from nay wiki page in edit mode.

Datatype  Decription  Rendered as  Return object 
String  a single line (default value)  textbox  java.lang.String
Boolean  true/false entry  checkbox  java.lang.Boolean
Date  a single line with calendar  date picker  java.util.date
timepoint   a selection of timePoints  combobox  com.polarion.alm.tracker.internal.model.TimePoint
user  a selection of users  combobox  com.polarion.alm.tracker.internal.model.TrackerUser
enum  a selection of the enumeration  combobox  com.polarion.platform.persistence.spi.DelegatingOption
project  a selection of the projects  combobox  com.polarion.alm.projects.internal.model.Project

Only string delivers a string, all other datatypes delivering the corresponding objects: 

{code}
(parameter:project|type=project)

{parameter-form}
Project: {parameter-editor:project}
{parameter-form-submit}
{parameter-form}

#if($pageParameters.project)
  project= $!pageParameters.project \\
  project= $!pageParameters.project.name \\
#end	
{code}

renderes as 

{code}
project= PObject(Project; subterra:data-service:objects:/default/AdavancedWikiSDK${Project}AdavancedWikiSDK) 
project= AdavancedWikiSDK 
{code}
#spoiler("" "{code}
REMOVE ":" at start of "parameter:answer" in next line
{:parameter:answer|type=boolean}
{parameter-form} 
	<table style="border:1px dotted red" cellpadding=10px>
	   <tr>
              <td>Are we able to script our own wiki pages after training?</td>  
	      #if($!pageParameters.answer)
	         <td>*Good Job!*</td>
	      #else
	         <td>Oh no :(</td>
	      #end
	   </tr>
	</table>
{parameter-editor:answer} 
{parameter-form-submit} 
{parameter-form}
{code}")
#spoiler("" "{code}
 http://YOURSERVER:YOURPORT/polarion/#/wiki/YOURSPACE/YOURDOCUMENTNAME?answer=true")
{code}")

This chapter gives an overview of the Polarion API usable from wiki pages. It is different from the WebService interface and also from the API which is usable from a Java program. The Wiki-Polarion-API may be extended, but this overview covers the standard Wiki-Polarion-API. The first reference can be found in the Polarion Help by querying "velocity variables". The table gives an overview of the objects available in the Velocity context.

The Polarion-API is part of the SDK and can be found here

The Polarion help (Adminitration Reference -> Context VariablesI) defines the classes Polarion adds to the Velocity context.

 Variable  API Class Description  Example  Link 
$calendarTool  com.polarion.wiki.util.CalendarTool This service provides getCalendar() methods in order to obtain an object of type java.util.GregorianCalendar. Milli seconds,
Day of month		  link 
$document com.polarion.alm.tracker.internal.model.Module Reference for the object representing the Polarion LiveDoc. Document items
custom fields
$me  Velocity only - the User Id of the current user You can use this variable to create personalized wiki pages All work items assigned to me
$page  com.polarion.alm.wiki.model.IWikiPage This service provides information of the current wiki page. Page project, Page space, Page name, Page Uri  link  
$plan com.polarion.alm.tracker.internal.model.Plan Reference for the Object representing the Polarion Plan. Planned items
due date
$platformService   com.polarion.platform.IPlatformService This service retrieves the Polarion product name and the currently used Polarion version Product, Version  link 
$projectService   com.polarion.alm.projects.IProjectService This service provides methods to manage projects. All users  link 
$securityService   com.polarion.platform.security.ISecurityService This service provides methods to manage users, roles and the relationsshios between them. Global roles for current user,
Project roles for current user		  link 
$testManagementService   com.polarion.alm.tracker.ITestManagementService This service provides methods to manage everything about test management. Get last test records  link 
$testRun com.polarion.alm.tracker.internal.model.TestRun The Object representing the current Test Run. Included test cases
$trackerService   com.polarion.alm.tracker.ITrackerService This most used service. It provides other objects from the system and many useful methods. Query work items  link 
$transactionService   com.polarion.platform.ITransactionService This service provides transaction methods. Every change of workitems must be surrounded by a transaction. The methods are beginTx(), endTx(), and commitTx().  link 
$wikiService   com.polarion.alm.wiki.IWikiService This service get information of the spaces and the pages within the spaces. List of all spaces  link 

The $trackerService provides many getter methods for other context variables. The next table lists all get methods which are returning new manager objects:

Manager  Class  Description  Link 
 moduleManager  com.polarion.alm.tracker.IModuleManager Manages creating, duplciating, branching of Polarion documents (and old fashion styled Modules Version 2011)  link 
 timePointsManager  com.polarion.alm.tracker.ITimePointsManager Provides methods for managing time points.  link 
 savedQueriesManager  com.polarion.alm.tracker.ISavedQueriesManager Provides methods for managing saved queries.  link 
 workflowManager  com.polarion.alm.tracker.IWorkflowManager Provides methods for managing the workflow.  link 
 exportManager  com.polarion.alm.tracker.IExportManager Manages the export templates and starts an export  link 
 importManager  com.polarion.alm.tracker.IImportManager Manages the import templates and starts an import  link 
 planningManager  com.polarion.alm.tracker.IPlanningManager Provides methods for updateing the LivePlan.  link 
 votingManager  com.polarion.alm.tracker.IVotingManager Provides methods for managing votings.  link 
 documentsManager  com.polarion.alm.tracker Deprecated:
This service provides methods working with Live Documents (Polarion 2010)		  link 
dataService   com.polarion.platform.persistence.IDataService  Is used for SQL searches  link 
trackerProject   com.polarion.alm.tracker.model.ITrackerProject  Provides you with methods to get enumeration fields.  link 

The Polarion API provides many methods to get workitem instances. One of the most commonly used method is the queryWorkItems method. The following API_Call returns all workitems of type requirement from the whole repository, the second call returns the requirements in the current proejct: 

{code}
#set($results=$trackerService.queryWorkItems("type:requirement","id"))
results= $results \\
#set($results=$trackerService.queryWorkItems("project.id:$page.project AND type:requirement","id"))
results= $results \\
{code}

The method returns a collection which can be iterated or the number of workitems returned can be determined: 

{code}
#set($number=$trackerService.queryWorkItems("type:requirement","id").size())
number= $number \\
#set($number=$trackerService.queryWorkItems("project.id:$page.project AND type:requirement","id").size())
number= $number \\
{code}

If a workitem is present the object of that workitem id can be obtained with the method getWorkItem: 

{code}
#set($wi=$trackerService.getWorkItem($page.project,"AWS-3"))
wi= $wi
{code}

#spoiler("" "{code}
#set($requirements=$trackerService.queryWorkItems("type:requirement AND project.id:$page.project","id"))

<table border=1 cellpadding=5px>
<th>Requirements</th>
	#foreach($requirement in $requirements)
	   <tr><td>{workitem:$requirement.getId()|fields=title|expand=no}</tr></td>
	#end
</table>
{code}")

Any changes to data can only be done within a transaction. If a title of a workitem should be provided by the string "prefix" a transaction must be opened and the workitem have to be saved before closing the transaction: 

{code}

##
## start transaction
##
$transactionService.beginTx()
    
##
## add the string prefix to the title
##
#set($wi_change=$trackerService.getWorkItem($page.project,"AWS-3"))
#set($prefix="Prefix")
$wi_change.setTitle($prefix.concat($wi_change.title))
$wi_change.save()

##
## end transaction, persist the work item changes
##
$transactionService.commitTx()

{code}
#spoiler("" "{code}
$transactionService.beginTx()
	#set($wi_change=$trackerService.getWorkItem($page.project,"EKIN-4"))
	$wi_change.addAprovee($projectService.getCurrentUser())
	$wi_change.save()
$transactionService.commitTx()
{code}")

Also a new workitem may be created. The method to create a new workitem is \$trackerService.createWorkItem(). After the method is called the attributes are filled and and the end the workitem is saved. Be careful when assignind a value to the description (or any custom field of type RuchText). The description has the datatype Text nach String. In order to get a new Text Object call the method \$objectFactory.newPlainText() with s String Parameter containing the value of the description.  

{code}

##
## start transaction
##
$transactionService.beginTx()
    
##
## create a new workitem
##
#set($newWi=$trackerService.createWorkItem($projectService.getProject($page.project)))

## set the workitem type
#set($enumTypes=$trackerService.getTrackerProject($page.project).workItemTypeEnum)
$newWi.setType($enumTypes.wrapOption("task"))

## set the title
$newWi.setTitle("Created by Velocity")

## set the description
#set($textObject=$objectFactory.newPlainText("This workitem was created by Velocity"))
$newWi.setDescription($textObject)

## save the workitem
$newWi.save()

##
## end transaction, persist the work item changes
##
$transactionService.commitTx()

{code}
#spoiler("" "{code}
$transactionService.beginTx()   
   #set($newWi=$trackerService.createWorkItem($projectService.getProject($page.project)))
   #set($enumTypes=$trackerService.getTrackerProject($page.project).workItemTypeEnum) 
	$newWi.setType($enumTypes.wrapOption("requirement"))   
	$newWi.setTitle("I like the training")   
   #set($textObject=$objectFactory.newPlainText("I will be an advanced wiki user")) 
	$newWi.setDescription($textObject)  
   #set($durationObject=$objectFactory.newDurationTime(2,4))
    	$newWi.setInitialEstimate($durationObject)      
	$newWi.save()    
$transactionService.commitTx()
{code}")

Polarion provides two different databases: a database which stores only the head revision of the object and a database, which stores all revisions of the objects. The database is read only so you can only get information out of it. you can´t write something directly inot the database. As return value of your query you always get work items so Polarion will check if current user is allowed to see this kind of data. The changes of the database is done by job which is atrted every day at 7pm. With the historic database it is possible to get data from the historie not having calculated it with a workitem metric.

The search of the data in the SQL index is much faster than in the lucene index. All of the referenced objects in a workitem like custom fields, work records, linked workitems, comments, and so are stored in tables in order to keep to database redundant free. It is easy to get all custom field values for a given workitem or to get all custom fields with a specific value and retrieve the workitem ids by a single SQL query. Also to get all work records within a specific time period it is only easy and fast.

The database ist part of the sdk documentation and can be found here 

Table 
  Description Example   Link
POLARION.WORKITEM Contains all kind of information about work items FK_MODULE, FK_PROJECT, 
C_STATUS, C_PREVIOUSSTATUS		  link 
STRUCT_WORKITEM_LINKEDWORKITEMS Table which gives you information which work items are linked by which role FK_P_WORKITEM, FK_WORKITEM,
C_ROLE		  link 
POLARION.WIKIPAGE Contains all kind of information about wiki pages FK_PROJECT, C_SPACEID, 
C_PAGENAME		  link 
POLARION.MODULE Contains all kind of information about Polarion Live Docs C_MODULENAME, FK_PROJECT  link 
POLARION.PROJECT Contains all kind of information about projects C_ID, FK_LEAD, FK_PROJECTGROUP  link 
POLARION.TESTRUN Contains all kind of information about test runs C_GROUPID, C_STATUS, C_TYPE  link 
POLARION.WORKRECORD Gives you information about workrecords of your work items C_PK, C_COMMENT,
C_DATE, C_TIMESPENT		  link 
POLARION.TIMEPOINT Contains all kind of information about timepoints FK_PROJECT, C_ID, C_TIME  link 
POLARION.USER  Contains all kind of information about Polarion users C_DISABLENOTIFICATIONS, C_EMAIL  link 

If you need to get the linked workitems from a workitem or if you need to get all workitems linked with a specific linkrole only on SQL query is necessary. The table to look for is 

{code}
STRUCT_WORKITEM_LINKEDWORKITEMS
{code}

This table contains all links if they are backlinks or links. The following SQL statement gets all backlinked workitems for a given workitem id: 

{code}
$trackerService.getDataService().sqlSearch(

SELECT WI.C_ID "Requirement",
(SELECT WI.C_ID 

FROM 
POLARION.WORKITEM WI 

WHERE 
WI.C_PK = LW.FK_WORKITEM) "Linked WI", LW.C_ROLE "Linkrole" 

FROM 
POLARION.WORKITEM WI 

LEFT JOIN 
POLARION.STRUCT_WORKITEM_LINKEDWORKITEMS LW ON WI.C_PK = LW.FK_P_WORKITEM 

LEFT JOIN 
POLARION.PROJECT PR ON WI.FK_PROJECT = PR.C_PK 

WHERE 
PR.C_ID = 'elibrary' 

ORDER BY 
WI.C_ID, "Linked WI")
{code}

and to get the linked workitems (TOP DOWN) 

{code}
$trackerService.getDataService().sqlSearch(

SELECT WI.C_ID "Requirement",
(SELECT WI.C_ID 

FROM 
POLARION.WORKITEM WI 

WHERE 
WI.C_PK = LW.FK_P_WORKITEM) "Linked WI", LW.C_ROLE "Linkrole"

FROM 
POLARION.WORKITEM WI 

LEFT JOIN 
POLARION.STRUCT_WORKITEM_LINKEDWORKITEMS LW ON WI.C_PK = LW.FK_WORKITEM 

LEFT JOIN 
POLARION.PROJECT PR ON WI.FK_PROJECT = PR.C_PK WHERE PR.C_ID = 'elibrary' 

ORDER BY 
WI.C_ID, "Linked WI")
{code}

Plugins can extend the core functionality of Polarion in different ways. The SDK documentation in your local Polarion installation folder C:/Polarion/polarion/SDK holds detailed step by step guide and numerous examples.

Possibilities for Plugins are for example:

  • Automating workflow actions
  • Setting complex conditions for a workflow action
  • Complex macros for the use in Wiki pages
  • Additional administration menus
  • Form extensions for Work Items
  • Jobs
  • Servlets

For each Plugin you need to create a Java class which either implements a given method, or is just a Standalone class which can be used in wiki code. Examples can be found in the Polarion Server's SDK folder.

As addition to the Java class(es) you will need a hivemodule.xml, which makes Polarion know what the class you just created shall be used for.

Here is an example of such a file for 1) workflow functions, 2) workflow conditions and 3) a wiki macro: 

{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<module id="com.polarion.example.workflow" version="1.0.0">

	<contribution configuration-id="com.polarion.alm.tracker.workflow.functions">
		<function name="ComputeTotalLifeTime"
			clazz="com.polarion.example.workflow.functions.ComputeTotalLifeTime">
			<parameter name="Fields" id="fields" />
		</function>
	</contribution>
	
	<contribution
		configuration-id="com.polarion.alm.tracker.workflow.conditions">
		<condition name="CommentExist"
			clazz="com.polarion.example.workflow.conditions.CommentExist">
		</condition>
	</contribution>
	
	<contribution configuration-id="com.polarion.alm.wiki.renderingContext">
		<item key="effortCalculator"
			value="instance:com.polarion.example.macros.CalculateEffort" />
	</contribution>
	
</module>
{code}

Data handling and execution with Polarion is often done by special Service Interfaces. often these can not be called directly from the context of the Java execution, but can be retrieved easily if you know the following line. Use this always if a Service Interface cannot be accessed directly by the context or other parameters:

In general:
I[name]Service service = (I[name]Service)PlatformContext.getPlatform().lookupService(I[name]Service.class);

concrete for the ISecurityService:
ISecurityService security = (SecurityService)PlatformContext.getPlatform().lookupService(ISecurityService.class);

Please remember that this can only be done in Java code and not in velocity! 

#spoiler("" "{code}

Answer for Question 1:

1) Prototype setter method in JobUnit class
2) Descriptor for paramater in getJobDescriptor in JobUnitFactory
3) Setter method according to Prototype
4) Local variable in the JobUnit class definition.

{code}")

#spoiler("" "{code}

public interface IOverdueJobUnit extends IJobUnit {

    static final String JOB_NAME = "overdue.job";
    
    void setQuery(String query);    
}
{code}")

#spoiler("" "{code}

public class OverdueJobUnitFactory implements IJobUnitFactory {

    public IJobUnit createJobUnit(String name) throws GenericJobException {
        return new OverdueJobUnit(name, this);
    }

    public IJobDescriptor getJobDescriptor(IJobUnit jobUnit) {
        BasicJobDescriptor desc = new BasicJobDescriptor("Overdue job", jobUnit);
        JobParameterPrimitiveType stringType = new JobParameterPrimitiveType(
                "String",
                String.class);
        desc.addParameter(new SimpleJobParameter(
                desc.getRootParameterGroup(),
                "query",
                "Query to be called",
                stringType));
        return desc;
    }

    public String getName() {
        return IOverdueJobUnit.JOB_NAME;
    }
    
    private final class OverdueJobUnit extends AbstractJobUnit implements IOverdueJobUnit {
    	
    	private String query;
    	
        public OverdueJobUnit(String name, IJobUnitFactory creator) {
            super(name, creator);
        }
        
       
        protected IJobStatus runInternal(IProgressMonitor progress) {
           ITrackerService trackerService = (ITrackerService) PlatformContext.getPlatform().lookupService(ITrackerService.class);
            
            progress.beginTask(getName(), 0);
            try {
                int results = trackerService.queryWorkItems(query, "id").size();
                getLogger().info("Job returned this amount of items: "+results);
              
                return getStatusOK(null);
            } finally {
                progress.done();
            }
        }
        
        public void setQuery(String query) {
            this.query = query;
        }
        
    }
}
{code}")

#spoiler("" "{code}
public class HelloWorld {

    public String helloWorld(){
        return "Hello World!";
    }
}
{code}")

The last example can be extended for any other type of Service.

To access the default API Services use the line:

IxxxService xxxService =

(IxxxService) PlatformContext.getPlatform().lookupService(IxxxService.class);

Just replace "xxx" with the name of the service, like "Tracker", "Security" or "Project".

The following Exercises will help you to get used to the techniques learned in the previous chapters. 

#spoiler("" "{code}

{parameter:weeks|type=string|value=10}

<div style="background-color:\#E1F0FF;padding:5px;">
{parameter-form}
<table cellpadding="3" style="background-color:\#E1F0FF">
<tr><td style="white-space:nowrap;">How many weeks in the past shall be shown?:</td><td>{parameter-editor:weeks|width=50px} </td></tr>
</table>
{parameter-form-submit}
{parameter-form-save}
{parameter-form}


</div>

#set($Integer = 0)
#set($weeks=$Integer.parseInt($pageParameters.weeks))

#highchartStart("Repository Item Count" "line" 1000 500)

#set($resultstring="")

#foreach($number in [$weeks..0])

  #set($date = $dateTool.getDate())
  #set($calendar = $dateTool.toCalendar($date))               
  
  #if ($number > 0)            
    #set($minusweeks = $Integer.parseInt("-$number"))
    $calendar.add(3, $minusweeks)	
    #set($date = $calendar.getTime())    
    
  #end
  
  #set($repoService = $polarionTool.repositoryService)
  #set($connection = $repoService.getReadOnlyConnection($polarionTool.location))
  #set($revision = $connection.getRepositoryState($date))
  
  #set ($projectId = $doc.getProject($doc.space) )
  #set ($dataService = $trackerService.getDataService()  )
  #set ($results=$dataService.sqlSearchInBaseline("SELECT WI.C_PK FROM WORKITEM WI","$revision").size())
  #set($formatString = $calendarTool.formatDate($date, "yyyy,MM,dd"))
  
  #if($resultstring == "")
  	#set($resultstring="Date.UTC($formatString),$results")
  #else
  	#set($resultstring="$resultstring : Date.UTC($formatString),$results")
  #end
  
#end


#addHighchartXYDataSet("Items in Repository" "$resultstring")

#addHighchartAdditionalOptions("options.plotOptions = {area:{stacking: 'normal'}};")
#addHighchartAdditionalOptions("options.xAxis.type = 'datetime';")

#highchartEnd()



{code}")
